And you'll see that the original Keystone follows a bit of a circuitous route and I think one of the answers to your question is the original Keystone pipe makes use of a bunch of pipes that's already there, it's the old gas pipe that we converted, and that's one of the reason why it's hard to compare the lengths of the two, because the conversion costs on that existing pipe was very, very cheap compared to the costs of building new.

The second is that you made the comments that the new Keystone would be an order of magnitude more expensive than the other one, that's not correct. It's not anywhere near an order of magnitude, it's a modest percentage more. It'll be a little bit more per mile because it's 36 rather than 30, means the amount of steel cost goes up. But I just wanted to make sure that we didn't leave you with the impression that's it's an order of magnitude i.e. 10 times as expensive, that's not the case.
Okay, great. And when do you plan to do an open season on that, on the expansion?
If all those discussions and negotiations come together, we hope within the next month or two, we will be able to announce an open season process.
Great, thanks very much.
Thank you.
Thank you. The next question is from Louis Shammy from Zimmer Lucas. Please go ahead

Hi, everyone. My question was regarding getting oil from Cushing to the Gulf Coast. Is there any possibility for a potential pipeline to just let's say more scale than this Keystone expansion or you just take the direct route from Cushing to Houston or Port Arthur.
Do you mean converting an existing line?
Either converting an existing line or building something new.

Well, we would build something new, that would be our plan from Cushing to Port Arthur, would be a new pipeline that we would build. We have looked at other pipes and generally they are not big enough or they don't go to the right place or things like that.

Particularly key in getting to the Gulf Coast, I think from our perspective, from Cushing was to get critical mass to move from Cushing to the Gulf Coast and right now our deliveries off the base Keystone system at Cushing are basically all spoken for by refiners in Cushing area. So there really isn't a lot of barrels that you can sort of convert south. So if you build a pipeline to go south, pick a volume, say 300,000 barrels a day, you need to put some volume into it at the top end to get it to the bottom end. And then when you look at sort of filling the pipes at the top end, to make a project economic, you've got to come back to Alberta for 300,000 barrels a day. It doesn't – it's not an economic proposition to come back for that small of a volume, back to Alberta and build right to the Gulf Coast, your fuel is more expensive than the other alternatives in the marketplace. So we looked a lot at an alternative that would just be could you gather enough crude at Cushing to build to the Gulf Coast and we couldn't assemble enough critical mass in our planning process to make that kind of proposal to the marketplace.

Okay that makes a lot of sense and answers my question. The other thing I wanted to ask about was regarding the U.S. Pipeline assets that you're currently holding in TransCanada that could potentially be asset monetizations in the future. Just to tick them off, I see GLGT, GTN, the ANR system and then your Southwest assets, are there any other assets that could potentially go in and what issues would surround each of those pipelines?

Let me go through your list. First of all we today have about 46% of Great Lakes that is in our MLP. So, we've already taken steps there, and we have 100% of our interest in Northern Border that's in the MLP. So there is not much there – no part of GPM is in the MLP, so we do think about that. But I just want to clarify that it's an illustrative option that I was discussing earlier, but GPM is certainly a candidate. The southern end of GPM serving Nevada is called and all of our interest in is already in the MLP. The North Baja line down at Southern California, we would not anticipate that going towards the MLP in the near term. We've got a lot of work and investments to do there. And pipes like if we owned 100% we might think about putting part of it into the MLP, it's a different question when we only own roughly 44%, we consider it, but I am just kind of running through them all for you.

My sense on ANR, we've got a lot of work to do there, and we've got terrific investment opportunity on the storage side. We don't think projects that have execution risk or technical risk in a substantive way are appropriate for the MLP. Our business model is to deal with those tissues, take that risk within TransCanada, create value which we would intend to capture for the TransCanada shareholders. And maybe at some point in the future put a part of those assets into the MLP, but I would not want to leave the impression that any significant transfer of ANR assets is going anywhere anytime in the near future. That's the kind of asset that we keep within TransCanada.

Sure, that makes sense. And being that the Great Lake System and the GTN system have both been in TransCanada for a while; I would expect that any kind of asset sale there would produce significant tax liability; is that correct?
Well, it would produce a taxable gain, I think, and we don't always think those are such bad things.
Okay. All right, well, thanks a lot.
Thank you.
There are no more questions registered at this time. I will now turn the meeting back over to Mr. Moneta. Please go ahead, sir.

Thanks very much to all of you for participating this afternoon. We appreciate your interest in the company. I know it's been a bit of a long day with our AGM earlier today; but once again, we appreciate your interest late on a Friday. Bye for now.
Thank you. The conference has now ended. Please disconnect your lines at this time. Thank you for your participation.
